advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIAGRAMS</strong></font><br><blockquote>PMI-80 diagram located in the case cover.<br> If you are interested in more diagrams of the PMI-80, dowload this zipped <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Tesla_PMI80_Diagrams.zip">file</a> holding three diagrams of the whole system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from an Amiga 3000 brochure.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>Texas Instruments home computer, simply unbeatable</i> <br><br> Notice that the man seems not to feel at ease with a computer keyboard and still doesn't use the right finger...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles da Silva</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>One found the same leaflet in various countries, translated in many languages.<br><br> Title was: 'Sirius 1, the professional computer to the power of 16' </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thank you boss !" <br><br> The ad incite employees to ask their boss to buy these Apricot systems...clever.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Canon AS-100. Programmed to succeed."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DECEMBER 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 12 years old, Nicolas discovered he was the terror of the aliens"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Altos emphasized its software package offer.<br><br> advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You also get the new ALTOS ACCOUNTANT, a completely integrated business accounting system...<br><br> There's more. You get the unique ALTOS COMPUTER TUTOR, the self-teaching tutorial that provides simple, self paced, step-by-step training that make using the computer easy...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Chuck Hunkle, who worked at MSI in 1977-79, kindly sent us the complete 1978 MSI catalog. All the pages are shown in the following pictures.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computers with a cool teacher" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>Upgrade kit to transform a Spectrum into a Spectrum +<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The new Epson QX-10 is unlike any personal computer you've never seen. It's a computer for people who don't have the time to learn computer; a computer you can be using within minutes...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DMS-15</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983 advert.<br><br> The DMS-15 is a DMS-3/F with a built-in 15 MB hard disk.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST VICTOR ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>with the original Victor design.<br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The Victor 9000. It's a desktop system computer designed to be a "cut above" the rest...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £99 IN JANUARY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTWARE CATALOGUE</strong></font><br><blockquote>AcornSoft software catalogue for the Electron</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the previous advert showing the various cards of the Gemini 80-BUS system.</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Dick Smith VZ-200 and VZ-300 were very popular in Australia and New Zealand from 1983 to 1990. The VZ200 was the same model as the VTech Laser 200.
Despite of its poor chicklet keyboard and short RAM space, users could find hundreds of programs from local magazines, Dick Smith store or from several very active VZ user clubs.
Several peripherals and add-on were quickly available, among them, a 16 KB RAM plug-in module, a tape recorder, a mouse, a Speech Synthesiser and later a floppy disc drive unit.
See a complete review of the VZ 200 in the 'Read more' page.

emulator.description: The emulator is written in Borland C++. It emulates a VZ200/300 with 34k RAM
emulator.name: VZEM

emulator.description: The VZ-200 has been added to this multi-emulator
emulator.name: Emulator2001

emulator.description: Emulator for the NTSC version of this computer
emulator.name: James's VZ 200 emulator

emulator.description: Play your VZ games in Windows
emulator.name: WinVZ

emulator.description: Emulates a lot of systems for all platforms.
emulator.name: MESS Project

computer.keyboard: 45 rubber keys, Basic instructions and graphic symbols
computer.name: VZ200
computer.peripherals: 16 KB RAM plug-in module, tape recorder,
computer.ports: Tape-recorder (600 bauds), TV (RF modulator), Composite video, Memory expansion port, general expansion port
computer.ram: 8 KB (6 KB for user, 2 KB for video) up to 24 KB
computer.sound: built-in piezzo speaker 1 voice, 2.5 octaves, 9 note lengths
